summary:
NOW YOU ALL LISTEN TO ME.
We NEED an A-force movie right the hell now.
I was waiting for a moment like the female team-up in...
body:
NOW YOU ALL LISTEN TO ME.

We NEED an A-force movie right the hell now.

I was waiting for a moment like the female team-up in Endgame since I was a kid. A moment that could make me cry of joy, laugh out of the warm feeling in my chest and my whole body shaking because how empowered I felt.

Please do this. Please make this happen. I need more people to feel the way I did.

title: Beautiful and Necessary: The Empowerment of "That Scene" at the end of Avengers: Endgame
body:
Beautiful and Necessary: The Empowerment of “That Scene” at the end of Avengers: Endgame

I am now four days out from my first and, so far, only viewing of Avengers: Endgameand I have thought about it every single day. My mind keeps drifting back to it, mulling it over, remembering moments that moved me, marveling at the storytelling that so captured and swept me up for those short three hours. One of the scenes that keeps drawing me back, both to re-experience my initial reaction and…

summary: my mom: why do you love captain marvel so much?? me, internally: she’s queer-coded so hard that even though it isn’t explicitly...
body:
my mom: why do you love captain marvel so much??

me, internally: she’s queer-coded so hard that even though it isn’t explicitly stated I can’t help but see her as the first gay superhero in the mcu canon. she’s incredibly close to another woman who she calls “baby” and whose child she help raised, says fuck you to gender roles, looks/dresses Like That, and is one of only two movies (the other being Thor: Ragnarok) that I can think of that doesn’t include an explicit romantic interest (which of course makes Marvel big cowards because she feels So Gay without them having to stick their necks out and actually say it)

me, to my mom: she’s hot

tags: you can love the work but not the woman
yes this is me having just watched room for the second time ever
the second watch is definitely better and more emotional
definitely starting to stan brie even though i hate the term stan
summary: I wasn’t really the biggest Brie Larson fan. I was actually one of the salty bitches that was shocked when she swept the awards...
body:
Brie

I wasn’t really the biggest Brie Larson fan. I was actually one of the salty bitches that was shocked when she swept the awards season for that one role: Ma in the 2015 movie, Room.

But after seeing Captain Marvel I decided to finally watch Room and it was only then that I understood why she won those awards: she deserved that. Every bit of it.

I gotta be honest. There were a couple of moments in Captain Marvel where I thought Brie could’ve done better, but the more I rewatch Captain Marvel, the more I get her portrayal of the role. Eventually, I fell in love with Carol Danvers, and I loved her even more in the Avengers: Endgame.

So now whenever I read about someone saying how she was a bad actress, I always remember that scene in Room where Ma was sitting in the chair with her hands on her mouth and crying in silence so that Jack wouldn’t hear her, as well as the part where she says goodbye to the room. If anyone needs a reminder of how good Brie Larson truly is as an actress, just go watch Room before passing your judgement.

Then we could talk.

body:
at this point i rly rly rly don’t give a shit what anyone’s supposed ‘reasons’ for disliking captain marvel or the female team-up scene from endgame are, i’m gonna assume they’re a misogynist and treat them as such.

like you’re fully aware of the drama surrounding cm and still have to pipe up to say 'oh but i don’t like brie larson/captain marvel/girl team-up because-’ shut the fuck up incel no one cares. you think your reasons are different and good? they’re not, and the only ppl who agree with you are assholes.

'oh so you’re saying no one is allowed to dislike captain marvel?’ yeah i am saying that actually. if you don’t like her you hate women. period, end of story.

'oh so you’re saying no one is allowed to dislike captain marvel?’ yeah i am saying that actually. if you don’t like her you hate women. period, end of story.

at this point i rly rly rly don’t give a shit what anyone’s supposed ‘reasons’ for disliking captain marvel or the female team-up scene from endgame are, i’m gonna assume they’re a misogynist and treat them as such.

like you’re fully aware of the drama surrounding cm and still have to pipe up to say 'oh but i don’t like brie larson/captain marvel/girl team-up because-’ shut the fuck up incel no one cares. you think your reasons are different and good? they’re not, and the only ppl who agree with you are assholes.

'oh so you’re saying no one is allowed to dislike captain marvel?’ yeah i am saying that actually. if you don’t like her you hate women. period, end of story.

at this point i rly rly rly don’t give a shit what anyone’s supposed ‘reasons’ for disliking captain marvel or the female team-up scene from endgame are, i’m gonna assume they’re a misogynist and treat them as such.

summary:
So last month my daughter’s friends bought her both the Captain Marvel dress and jacket for her birthday:
She was wearing the...
body:
Your “Aww” story for the day

So last month my daughter’s friends bought her both the Captain Marvel dress and jacket for her birthday:

She was wearing the jacket last night at Disney Springs, and apparently couldn’t go a few steps without some little girls running up and yelling “CAPTAIN MARVEL!”

This warms my heart for so many reasons. :)

(On a side note, she sent us a picture of her wearing the entire ensemble and I told Red, “I want to try that on (meaning of course the jacket) while we’re down there.” She looked at me for a moment and said, “I don’t think the dress would suit you.”)
